meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny!

So, it's time to put on our big-boy pants and review AEW: Fight Forever, the new wrestling game that's got everyone talking. Now, I know what you're thinking - "Is this a game-changer for wrestling fans?" Well, let me tell you, it's not entirely a slam dunk (see what I did there?). But before we get into the nitty-gritty, let's take a look at what some of our friends in the gaming press have to say.

IGN gave it a 60, saying that AEW: Fight Forever has "unrealized potential." Ouch! Game Informer scored it a 63, calling it a strong foundation for future growth. Slant Magazine was more optimistic, giving it an 80 and praising its accessibility and unique flair. Gaming Age handed out a 67, commending the game's chaotic fun and ease of play. SpazioGames came in with a 65, criticizing the lack of gameplay and content improvements. And finally, COGconnected gave it an impressive 86, calling it the best wrestling game since WWF No Mercy.

Now that we've got the critical consensus out of the way, let's get to what I think!

Honestly, AEW: Fight Forever is a mixed bag. On one hand, the game has some really great ideas - the bouncy animations are a lot of fun, and the character design is spot on. The action is fast-paced and easy to pick up, making it perfect for casual players or wrestling fans looking for a more arcade-style experience.

On the other hand, there are some serious issues holding this game back. The story mode is poorly written and lacks direction, making it feel like a chore to get through. And don't even get me started on the bugs - I lost count of how many times I had to restart a match because something went haywire.

So, what's my take? Well, as someone who loves wrestling (and hates bugs), I think AEW: Fight Forever has some great bones but needs a lot more work. It's not a bad game by any stretch, but it doesn't quite live up to its potential.

If you're an AEW fan, you might still enjoy this release - just don't expect too much out of the single-player mode. And hey, at least it's a great alternative to those WWE games that always seem to be getting criticized.

So, there you have it! That's my take on AEW: Fight Forever. It's not the best game ever, but it's not the worst either. And hey, who knows - maybe that DLC will help turn things around?

Thanks for reading, and until next time, keep on gaming (and grumbling about bugs)!
